data.title: The Cincinnati Post...
data.meta_description: Bearcat Banter:  The #1 Board for Cincinnati Bearcats sports on the internet.
data.text:
There have been other threads which have touched on this issue, but I would like to address this as it relates to UC...

I am very concerned about the demise of the Post...mainly because it eliminates any competition for information on the print side...given that the media here barely do their job on the first place...and we have a real problem concerning the reporting of information...

I am doubly concerned given the staff at the Enquirer...

it has to be the only major newspaper I know of (aside from the Post) to only have one sports columnist...and the beat reporters are unmotivated or just plain don't care (Why doesn't Koch have a blog?)...

It has long been my feeling that certain people in town have been given a free media pass (Marvin Lewis, for one)...the removal of one of the two papers exacerbates that problem and only hinders the flow of information...

We now have a city that has one newspaper, and one company that owns all of our radio stations...the TV guys are all old buddies and are happy with their place in life...

So where does that leave the fan and the public?...

Exactly where they want you to be...given the information they want you to get, and only that information...

Trent, Josh, Lonnie, etc....my hat is off...thank you...I celebrate the past and am wary of the future...

Paging Mr. Orwell...

Post: #2

RE: The Cincinnati Post...

NVExel Wrote:There have been other threads which have touched on this issue, but I would like to address this as it relates to UC...

I am very concerned about the demise of the Post...mainly because it eliminates any competition for information on the print side...given that the media here barely do their job on the first place...and we have a real problem concerning the reporting of information...

I am doubly concerned given the staff at the Enquirer...

it has to be the only major newspaper I know of (aside from the Post) to only have one sports columnist...and the beat reporters are unmotivated or just plain don't care (Why doesn't Koch have a blog?)...

It has long been my feeling that certain people in town have been given a free media pass (Marvin Lewis, for one)...the removal of one of the two papers exacerbates that problem and only hinders the flow of information...

We now have a city that has one newspaper, and one company that owns all of our radio stations...the TV guys are all old buddies and are happy with their place in life...

So where does that leave the fan and the public?...

Exactly where they want you to be...given the information they want you to get, and only that information...

Trent, Josh, Lonnie, etc....my hat is off...thank you...I celebrate the past and am wary of the future...

Paging Mr. Orwell...

You would expect that with the increased circulation and revenue that will come from the closing of the Post that the Enq would pick up 1 or 2 Post sports reporters.

They will lose the revenue they receive from printing the Post, but they must have pursued "custom" printing to fill the open time.

I wonder if Dayton D N might consider going after some of the Cincinnati market & hire some Cinci writers and publish a "metro edition" covering our area?

Post: #6

RE: The Cincinnati Post...

I'm sure you'd rather have Peter Bronson, one of King George's butt boys to show you the golden road. By the way, how is Comrade Bushki on immigration? Let 'em in? Sounds socialist to me...........

Actually, the Post hasn't been much of an alternative political voice for some time, and that's pretty much the only way a paper can be an alternative voice, in editorials. The Enquirer has been crap for a long time, and it will be the next one down the chute.

Shame, either way, it was nice having two papers.

We old folks can remember when the Post would endorse every non -Gop candidate regardless of qualifications for the job while the Enquirer would endorse every GOP candidate.

Funny, but maybe City Beat could fill that void if it were not so anti-everything.

Can we expect anything from Peter Bronson other than his usual conservative posturing? Probably not. That's what the old dinsaurs around here want.

My conservative friends, I have been making an effort to watch Meet the Press and the other Sunday a.m shows when candidates are interviewed at length. I saw Giuliani the other day, and will keep watching. Should be interesting.[/i]
